reviewText:
VVVVVV is perhaps the most fun I've ever had being tortured with a game this side of Super Meat Boy.

It's a sublime DOS inspired platformer where inverting the gravity has replaced your jump button, requiring you to completely rethink how you approach a level. Platforms are setup in a way that require incredibly precise, conscious flips and movement to surpass, at times feeling almost impossibly difficult. But VVVVVV is never unfair, offering you an abundance of checkpoints and excessively precise controls that caused me to surprise myself with what I was capable of.

The nonlinear design also allows you to opt out of some of the most challenging rooms, or revisit them later when you feel better in tune with the game. Completing the game will test your mettle regardless, but the sense of accomplishment and the ever present feeling that you can possibly surpass any challenge given just one more time makes it impossible to give up and extremely rewarding when you do eventually succeed (though all the same, Doing it the hard way" will forever haunt my nightmares).

VVVVVV's vision is so strong and consistent

reviewText:
Time for a controversial review. I’ve played this game on and off for the past 5 years, and I’ve gradually come to realize it's not that great. I’ll try to explain why.

To get one thing out of the way, the music is fantastic. The chiptune album “PPPPPP” is a true modern classic, catchy and energetic and well-produced. The game sells for $5, but I’d be willing to pay $20 for the soundtrack alone. It’s that good. Even after hearing these tunes for 5 years, most of them still haven’t gotten old to me. But chances are you’ve already heard the music and know this for yourself.

To get another thing out of the way, I think the visuals are awesome. The minimalistic art throws back to a time older than the NES, and the ever-changing neon colors are strange and mysterious in their simplicity, and demand to be explored. In a way, the game itself is a fitting music video to one of the greatest chiptune albums there is.

So, what do I dislike about this game? Well, where do I start…?

The game is built around a novel idea – flipping the gravity of your character instead of jumping – and then spends an hour or two trying to pretend this mechanic has no crippling limitations before just giving up.  And I’m not exaggerating here: the entire game can be consistently beaten in about 30 minutes. The first time I played it, it took me about 50. Finding all the hidden trinkets can take about an hour more, depending on how many tries it takes you on the “Prize for the Reckless” and “Veni, Vidi, Vici” challenges.

Most games which are built around a central gimmick will try to expand it with additional game mechanics. VVVVVV comes up with about four new mechanics to complement its gravity-flipping gimmick: conveyer belts, automatic-flip lasers, auto-scrolling rooms, and rooms that wrap around the edges. It then uses each of these mechanics in a tiny dungeon area and almost nowhere else. Two of the game’s areas use a somewhat irritating mechanic where you have to lead a friend around, with the level design poking fun at the fact that your friend has no common sense and you have to do everything for them. As far as new ideas are concerned, that’s pretty much it.

The central hub area, which comprises the majority of the map, is mostly just empty space: no enemies, no platforming puzzles, nothing but a few spikes here and there and a few of the collectable trinkets hidden away in corners. Even the interesting mazes are scarce. The hopelessly catchy track “Passion for Exploring” plays in the central hub, but in this case, “exploration” means just repeatedly falling through dozens of empty screens and searching for the next dungeon entrance. The overworld is also littered with dozens of checkpoints and teleporters which you will never use because there’s just nothing out there. They could have removed it entirely, replacing the hub with a series of teleporters to the dungeons, and the game hardly would have lost anything.

The game is touted as a “super hard” and “tough as nails” platformer. If that’s the case, it’s the easiest “super hard” platformer I’ve ever played. Some parts are hard, but there’s no steady sense of progression; the difficulty is mostly just limited to a few problem rooms which may take hundreds of deaths each, but otherwise the whole game is smooth sailing. If you want real difficulty, you can try no-death mode or the time trials, but it just amounts to repeatedly playing the same ridiculously short game until you get it perfect. In this case, the difficulty is mostly just self-imposed rather than the work of a level designer. Personally, I’ve spent the most amount of time on the Super Gravitron, a fearsomely difficult mini-game that was probably the spiritual precursor to Super  Hexagon.

The game’s story might as well not be there. I can summarize the story as follows: “You are some kind of captain of some kind of crew piloting some kind of ship, which crash-lands on some kind of planet due to some kind of disturbance. In order to escape, you need to deactivate some kind of device located in some kind of alternate dimension.” I’m not exaggerating. Nothing is explained. This story could have been mysterious and compelling, but instead it chooses to go the “self-referential humor” route by having the characters poke fun at checkpoints and the level design, while they’re not busy talking about nothing.

And for those who say “Why would you play this game for the story?” I propose that you consider this: the game’s story could have been better if you removed all of the dialogue. The story is told perfectly through the visuals. The explosions, lost crew members, and alternate dimensions are all self-explanatory, and it would have left all the details up to the imagination. Captain Viridian would have made a great silent protagonist that you could have projected your own motivation into. Instead, the characters are all given completely needless speaking lines which don’t convey anything, and I’m just left wondering why anyone bothered to write dialogue.

TL,DR: Aside from the superb music and the visuals, VVVVVV feels like a game that was hastily thrown together. The difficulty is schizophrenic, rather than a fine-tuned progression curve. The overworld map is mostly empty space, as though the level designer had tried filling it with enemies and mazes but finally said “screw it, nothing works” and deleted everything. The story had no effort behind it. Interesting game mechanics are few and far between, and are only used for a few rooms each. The bonus game modes are needless masochism that are far too great of a difficulty jump from the main game. Overall, it feels more like an hour-long proof of concept than a full-fledged game exploring the possibilities and implications of its main gravity-flipping gimmick.

Yes, it was influential. Yes, it rode the very first wave of indie games back when Steam was gaining steam. Yes, the music is crazy good. All things considered, I respect this game. But after five years of playing and reflecting on it, I can’t help but see it as a short, pointless waste of time with no interesting gameplay statements to make (even for its time) and no heart put into it. It’s style-over-substance. But hey, it’s got a great style, so I can’t quite fault it for that. I know a lot of people love this game. I loved it for a while, but now that I've noticed its flaws I can't shake the sour taste this game leaves me with.

I know that few will agree with my sentiment, but hopefully I’ve explained my thoughts adequately.

And finally, all achievement hunters but the most dedicated should stay far, far away. This is one brutal 100%.

reviewText:
This game, VVVVVV, it calls itself. A mess of letters that blend together into a mess of jagged lines, as if to trace one's path through life in a retrospective essay of Adobe Flash and Steam winter sales. It infuriates me. But not for the reasons one might expect, no, not the usual cries of difficulty and despair.

I double-click the name in my Steam library and prepare for the worst. Forty nine cents, I say. This game cost me less than a round of slightly clogged arteries from the local fast food joint and was paid for entirely by selling virtual headwear and trading cards to those less fortunate than myself. Surely I will be able to find some modicum of enjoyment of this mess of Flash. Flash? Perhaps not! The forums of the Internet tell me that at one point it was remade in a proper programming language. As such, the game can suffer random slowdowns in fullscreen and neither the Steam overlay nor capture software such as Fraps will recognize the game. I found myself unable to take and upload screenshots of my trials in this pixelated, single-colored world, for all to see but none to comment on. A Google search leads to a Steam forum post regarding then-'soon' updates for overlays, achievements and the Cloud. The famous Cloud. This post dates from over two years ago. Nothing has been done since. Alt-tabbing the game will lock your cursor in the corner of your screen and sometimes just crash. This game was not built on Source, they tell me. They're lying to me.

The game itself controls acceptably. Sometimes I find myself sliding off platforms and into hazards and sometimes getting stuck inside either. Platformers should not have slippery controls like this, but the air control is precise and exact. Why is there such a difference? Is there an underlying message to be found here, perhaps describing the trials of Man trapped in his earthly plane? I would hope not, as this game predates the trend of waves upon waves of lazy, 'deep' indie ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t by several years. To the untrained eye it appears to fit quite well, though, with the simplistic graphics and chiptune soundtrack.

This. This is where this executable of poor optimization and developer laziness gets to me. The game's art style is obviously meant to harken back to an era of dial-up and diskettes, in truth even earlier than both. Simple graphics and single color palettes attempt to imitate the limitations of old, yet miss the mark entirely. The developers want you to think you're playing a Commodore 64 game, down to including an imitation tape deck load screen upon startup, and yet they so clearly miss the appeal of the C64. Why go for plain, blocky graphics when it was capable of so much more? Why use a soundtrack consisting entirely of generic chiptunes churned out in Fruityloops in an afternoon when the Commodore was famous for its SID chip, used even today for its unique sound and characteristics? This was perhaps the biggest indicator of Vee Six's origins.

Vee Six? Yes, that will do. I feel it fits this game nicely. You wanted the big American V8 with more displacement than the total Coke bottles in a shopping cart at Wal-Mart, but instead went for the more frugal six-cylinder for better gas mileage. Perhaps it shows up under a different name, like Grand Sport or Touring, but the illusion disappears as soon as the hood is opened and the guts of the machine become visible. Likewise, you wanted a game that harkens back to the days of incredible difficulty, but without actually playing a game from that era, so you bought Vee Six.

It was quite ahead of its time, really, this poor little game. Perhaps it actually started the trend of retro-throwback games that only appear as such to the untrained, Mountain Dew chugging eye, taking a small break from his endless stacks of semi-futuristic first person shooters starring Sgt. Master Sgt. Technician of Operations Captain Slabmeat and his sidekicks, Alpha Team Bravo Charlie Omega. I have doubts about his ability to find such a game, though. This seems like one meant for that other audience, the one that cuddles into their woolen hat at the corner coffee house while typing on their ridiculously overpriced, shining white laptop and adjusting their lensless, thick-framed glasses. A game for those who want to go back... but not really, because they never experienced what they would be going back to in the first place. An imitation that falls apart like that disgusting hipster's Volkswagen as it gets driven around a small upstate city in New York looking for guys in skinny jeans and no shoes while struggling from no oil changes to no oil changes.

So. An interesting word, 'so.' Both a statement and a question. So what? So this is a review, after all. Reviews have to have one final word, else the whole page might as well be used as a paper airplane to send your thoughts and dreams. In these modern times of instant messaging and ironic tendencies, no one has time to read more than exactly one hundred forty-four characters without requesting a short-form so their attention deficit disorder-afflicted minds can process that one tidbit of information before riding the rollercoaster of latest trends down the next incline while that child in the back row vomits all over himself and the poor sod sitting beside. Do I recommend this game? The question weighed heavily on my mind for days on end, pervading every waking moment with its incessant inquisition.

Yes. I suppose I can recommend this game, if you enjoy throwing money at walls to throw a small, single-color, virtual person at a wall over and over. I move my mouse and hesitantly click the checkmark instead of the thumbs-down icon. Nobody reads negative reviews, after all, and unfortunately there is no option for 'indifference' or perhaps 'Yes, but only if on sale first.' I paid forty nine American pennies for a sadomasochism simulator in the guise of a 'retro' platformer game.

I should have found two more quarters in my couch and bought a burger.

reviewText:
If you had told me before VVVVVV that a difficult platformer with a simple concept that is based around precision-timing jumps would not only not give me a burning desire to throw the controller at the screen in frustration, but that I would actually have a hard time letting go of said controller for almost the whole duration of the game, you probably would've gotten a face full of sarcastic laughter (which sounds eerily like the Super Meat Boy tune). Or, more likely, I would've ignored your suggestion until I got the game half-free as part of a Humble Bundle (sorry, brother, your suggestions are the best!) and had no excuse not to play this highly-praised game.

I enjoy quality platforming as much as most gamers and don't mind the difficulty that typically comes with such games, especially when they are indie-made. But I need to be in a very specific mindset if I am to endure countless re-attempts at the slightest mistake and I run out of that energy eventually regardless of how far I got in the game. VVVVVV rectifies the image of indie platformers you have in your head with a surprising breath of clarity - even the confusing name makes perfect sense after staring at those same spikes room after room. Instead of jumping, you switch gravity back and forth so that you're either standing on ground or on the ceiling - and that's all there is to it. No upgrades, no weapons, everything you come across is doable from the get-go. The world is open, reminiscent of Metroidvania games, but even with a minimal plot and the ability to choose your own path, playng is straight-forward and you never feel lost.


What could've been only a gimmick or proof-of-concept-gameplay comes together as a tight, addictive package, thanks to the gratituous use of checkpoints. There is typically at least one in each room and as you die you reappear next to it without further hassle, so once you figure out how to gravity-change yourself out of the next pickle or ace the pixel-tight patterns of moving obstacles, you're safe again.  Dying constantly is not only allowed, it's celebrated, with the total number of deaths in your current playthrough proudly displayed in the menu. There are Steam achievements for finishing the game with a small number of deaths, but you don't have to care about that unless you really want to. You can collect trinkets in the game, which unlocks some extras, and there are a few which can test your patience, but thanks to the checkpoints, you don't have to memorize minutes of tough manouvers; it's all finely chopped down.

Of course, the platforming in this game is still challenging - if you didn't enjoy the joys of precision jumping in a game like the original Super Mario Brothers, you probably won't enjoy this. But the game isn't needlessly or falsely difficult. VVVVVV presents itself as exactly as it is, trial-and-error gameplay in the word's most positive sense. You can focus on the platforming puzzles without being punished for dying while trying to get a feel" of each room's pattern. Each new checkpoint reached feels like a little win and you get through even the more difficult parts with the knowledge that the gameplay is logical and rewards your patient learning

reviewText:
-Quick Review-
I'm still not really sure why it's called VVVVVV, I remember playing the game expecting the game to be chaotic, but it actually was a fairly entertaining game and interesting game. The game is a 2D exploration/adventure game that feels like something I would play on a classic GameBoy.
-Detailed breakdown review-
Story:  You are the captain of a ship and you have lost your crew mates! you need to go save them and get collect various artifacts of the strange world you're now stranded on. This game will give you various fun, enjoyable puzzles.
At the time that I'm writing this review (08/20/14) I haven't completed the story, I stopped half way through, and then achievements were added so now I've boosted up when I want to complete and play this game. :D

Game Play: I cannot say enough about simple controls. I love simple controls, jump, right, left, up, down. That's all you need.
As I said earlier, the game plays like something you might play on a Classic GameBoy cartridge, I've never had a problem playing games which low graphics, it actually makes the game more fun and easier to play on mobile or smaller devices like laptops.
The puzzles can sometimes be challenging but the game itself is very simple in nature and quite forgiving. As you progress or try to get special extra's the game challenges you more. I installed this game without expecting anything at all, and I was pleasantly surprised to find myself enjoying the game. (I've played 32 minutes worth of content before achievements were added)

Achievements: At this time I haven't earned any of these achievements, but I had a glance and most of the achievements seem pretty straight forward. Beat the game, beat the game without dying X amount of times, do this interesting thing for X amount of time, Beat the game in X amount of time.
The achievements look a bit last-luster and uninteresting but there really isn't much they can do with the game, and ultimately it's impressive that there are achievements at all for a 2D game with graphics this low.

Price: VVVVVV is currently $4.99 That's a bit high of a price for a game if you don't plan to play it, I got the game for $1 on a 90% off sale in the steam 2013 Summer Sale. There is also a demo version of the game, which I would recommend trying out.
Whenever there's a Demo you should try out the demo just to see if you actually like the content inside the game. It's good to read reviews for how a game plays, but testing out the graphics and game play for yourself is second too none.

Conclusion: Most people are put off by the idea of playing a 2D game, especially one with very low graphics that looks like it was made for a very old game system, but I've always enjoyed games, both high quality, low quality, and in-between.
I recommend this game to anyone who's looking for a short little game to play through that won't take up much memory, and has a few hours to burn. I also recommend it to anyone who already knows they don't mind low quality graphics in their video games.

reviewText: VVVVVV is a game that transports my brain 30 years back in time to my childhood. In many ways, it looks like something that could have existed on the Atari 2600, but that's not really true - games didn't exist back then that were this polished, either design- or control-wise. So this is really the best of both worlds for people like me: great nostalgia value, but also designed to look and play great for modern times. But what is VVVVVV, anyways? It's a 2D exploration platformer with only one character action - the ability to 'flip' gravity up or down. You might think that having only one mechanic would really limit the game's playability, but it doesn't. There are enough fresh twists sprinkled throughout the game to keep it interesting from start to finish (around 3-4 hours for the main quest). It's really a brilliantly designed game, with just the right amount of challenge. This should be a no brainer for 2D platforming fans, and especially for those who grew up gaming in the 80s.

reviewText:
Ah, VVVVVV. I got this as part of a pack of games during the 2010 steam holiday sale. I don't even know what else was in the package. Five dollars for this game, by itself, is a fricken bargain. The graphics are aggressively retro, bringing you back to your DOS days of command prompts and computers with no harddrive(er, if you're old, like me). The soundtrack is sublime. The controls are deliberately floaty and imprecise; Like with Super Meat boy, this is a game where you need to learn restraint in order to achieve precision, a game where you're constantly sliding after landing and flying further than you intended. Every action has inertial consequences. But unlike super meat boy, it's less reactive, its inertial force harder to fight, and thus more consistent and predictable yet no less difficult. Where the slightest backtap could mean spikey death in SMB, which makes Meatboy feel weightless and heavy at the same time, VVVVVV feels consistently heavy but low-gravity, and therein lies its brilliance.

Fantastic. Just really good.

PS: I played this to completion before they added achievements; I don't know how complete I'd have gotten it but I do know I finished the game with all the shiny trinkets(though, it must be said, dying hundreds of times along the way).

reviewText:
From the outside, VVVVVV may just look like another retro-styled game that uses its retro factor to hide the fact that it's just another generic platformer. While the former may be true, this is definitely not your average platformer.

The story of this game is simple: you're a captain of a spaceship and your crew has been scattered through another dimension due to some interference. You need to find them and stop the interference. The graphic style is heavily inspired by the Commodore 64's graphics, while the sountrack is more reminiscent of that of the NES. Both of these work great together, although they might not be amusing for someone is tired of retro styled indie games.

VVVVVV is a metroidvania game: meaning that you can explore the dimension you're in looking for all sorts of things (crew members, trinkets, teleporters). What makes VVVVVV so special however is that you can't jump, but you can flip gravity so that you'll go up instead of down, and vice-versa. The concept is easy to learn (but incredibly hard to master), and leads to many creative levels. There will be some levels *cough*Doing Things The Hard Way*cough* that will usually frustrate the crap out of you, but at the same time you'll have a blast trying to figure out how to get through them (unless you are very easily frustrated, in which case, you should stay away from this game). On top of the main game, there are tons of other features that will keep you playing for hours, such as collecting all of the trinkets, time trials, various game modes (flip mode where the entire game is flipped upside down and no death mode where if you die once you have to restart the game), and even a level creator.


VVVVVV will make you want to break your keyboard and you will love every minute of it. What makes this game even better is that it's often on sale for a low price (sometimes even $0.49!). This is a must have for those looking for a challenge.

reviewText:
VVVVVV is one of the best games I've played in recent times & I would not hesitate to call it 2010's Game Of The Year ahead of Red Dead Redemption & Super Meat Boy.
The gameplay revolves around the simple mechanic of the jump button in a retro platformer inverting gravity instead of jumping. This alone already makes for some very original & interesting puzzles, however the game doesn't stop there. The level design, in a Half-Life 2 way, introduces new gameplay mechanics every so often, many of which is only featured in the segment that it was introduced in. This provides lots of variety to the platforming while constantly challenging the player in new ways. Mix that with awesome music & Atari-style art direction & you've got a slam dunk in game design.
The game is of an appropriate length for it, clocking in at 2-3 hours for the main story mode, however there are custom levels you can play as well. The story is good, well delivered & actually has a fair layer of depth to it. The information nodes scattered around the game world provide some insight to the nature of the incident. It isn't as deep as Half-Life or F.E.A.R. but that's okay since VVVVVV is a 2-3 hour retro platformer where that kind of stuff isn't expected, not an first-person action game.
The only flaw would be the hyper-sensitive controls, though they are more consistent than something like Super Meat Boy, so mastering them is easier.
VVVVVV sets a new standard for not only 2d platformers or indie games but video games in general.

reviewText: Despite the obscure name, VVVVVV is 2D Platformer with simple graphics, simple gameplay and a simple story. When your ship crash's and your crew is scattered out in space, it's your job as the captain to round them up in order to get the ship flying again. The game's layout is in the same style as Metroid, as the map is huge and it's easy to get lost. You basically move around while defying and re-defying gravity to navigate through levels. Checkpoints are scattered everywhere and your going to need them from all of the times you die. There are 20 trinkets to find in order to unlock the jukebox or something as the music in this game is epic with its catchy tunes. Graphics are simple classic 8-bit style with bizarre looking enemies, almost feels like something out of a Commodore 64 or ZX Spectrum game. If there's one thing this game is known for, it's challenge, there is a lot of tricks and puzzles in navigating through the place and you really have to be quick on your feet and plan ahead on what to do. Overall VVVVVV is a great challenging game that feels like a throw back to the old PC games.

reviewText: There are really two types of people in this world. Those who hate maddeningly frustrating twitch platformers like this one, and those who hate maddeningly frustrating twitch platformers like this one so much, they can't stop playing them. Spiritual elder sibling to You Have To Win The Game
date:
VVVVVV is to the Commodore 64 platformer of yore what its CGA cousin is to the DOS platformer of yore, and I cannot possibly recommend both games enough.

To paraphrase the words that prefaced the Dungeons and Dragons rulebook so many years ago, those gamers who lack patience, those who don't care for Monty Mole's adventures through sprawling maps of tricky-to-navigate rooms, who feel no thrill upon waking up with Lester in the suspended cage in that famously Another World, who do not enjoy rubbing their palmheel raw on the molded plastic grip of an old one-button joystick with a nine-pin connector or trying hundreds of times to see what lies beyond that maddening gauntlet of hazards, even if it's just a blank room that hasn't been visited before, will not be likely to find VVVVVV to their tastes. But those whose curiosity knows no bounds and whose frustration tolerance rivals that of a Zen master will find this game the answer to their SID-soundtracked, load-star-comma-eight-comma-one prayers.

The very simple graphics may put you off; don't let them. The six Vs of the title, the cast of the game, take a little getting-used-to, certainly, and I admit, I would have liked a slightly less stylized (if still period-appropriate) character model, but their simple Carcassone-like iconic cuteness grows on you, or at least a tolerance to it accumulates. The characters have two recognizable facial expressions, and their paddle-like, boxy heads are sized, I suspect, to accommodate those easily-recognizable expression changes. Without sharing spoilers, I should note that it becomes clear, later in the game, that their box-headed design was thematically intentional. If you don't like it, relax, and don't let that stop you from enjoying this amazing game.

The backgrounds, with their stylized metal plating, single-color enemies, and two-plane-deep parallax scrolling gamefield, will be immediately recognizable to C64 fans, as will the bombastic, cheerful, strident soundtrack of in-game looped hits by Magnus Pålsson. While You Have To Win The Game offers only monophonic sound cues, in line with its pre-soundcard DOS-and-PC-speaker pedigree, VVVVVV feels much less stark and empty for its consistently cheerful, upbeat and hopeful tone, and the soundtrack plays a huge role in creating that atmosphere of Let's play space explorers!" Saturday morning excitement.

reviewText:
Don't let my Steam time fool you, I've had this game on my 3DS since 2012, and put nearly 24 hours into it. VVVVVV is a fantastic Indie platformer where instead of jumping, you flip, or reverse gravity. You can only flip whilst on the ground, and can only move left or right while moving through the air.
VVVVVV has a simple but charming tale of a spaceship crew that crash into another dimension, and you must rescue all your crewmembers. The story will take you 2-2 and a half hours to complete if you don't speedrun. (And might I add, this is a beautiful game to speedrun) However, there are collectible trinkets which can be found, as well as a secret area when all 20 are found, Speedrunning missions, and a no death gamemode. A level editor and support for player generated levels also extends the life of the game.
The graphics for this game aren't anything special, but move smoothly as they should, despite the pixel art design. They really feel like something from the classic arcades of yesteryear, but while remaining a modern touch in the backgrounds.
The soundtrack in VVVVVV is fantastic, you will be jamming to it admist playing. Great 8-Bit chiptunes that complement the gameplay.
The game is quite difficult at times, but checkpoints are frequent and rewarding, allowing challenging gameplay, without the risk of losing lots of progress.

reviewText: VVVVVV is so much better than I was expecting. For a game with only three actions available (move left, move right, reverse personal gravity), VVVVVV offers an impressive amount of variety in its challenges. Mix in a good sense of humor, some lovable characters, the catchy chiptune soundtrack, Commodore 64-inspired graphics, a bit of Metroidvania-esque exploration, an interesting storyline, thousands of spikes, and the perfect balance of difficulty and fun, and just wow. You've got all sorts of good times ahead of you. You've also got a handful of bonus modes (time trials, flipped game, etc.) and secrets to keep you busy afterwards, a respectable number of options (such as invincibility, and an analogue mode that'll probably just hurt your eyes), a level editor, and best of all: player levels! A selection of the best levels created by various people (including one by everyone's favorite Minecraft god, Notch) almost ensures you'll get a fair amount of playtime and fun out of this one.

The game has a very nice Commodore 64 feel to it, and the character's velocity is linear, not quadratic (you don't speed up as you fall down). The soundtrack is awesome (seriously, listen to the trailer), and the game was well worth the $5 I paid for it.

My one problem with this game was the level editor.  The Script Editor, like the Commodore 64 it's based on, is difficult to use without a guide.  I can't figure the thing out!

VVVVVV is a great little platformer built around a single unique mechanic: instead of jumping, you have the ability to switch gravity up and down. This mechanic leads to some of the most inventive and challenging platforming gameplay I've ever encountered. Every single room becomes a platforming puzzle as you try to figure out how to use gravity to move through hostile environments without dying, which you will do often. Luckily, the game wastes no time respawning you at the nearest checkpoint, which are liberally sprinkled throughout the environment. VVVVVV also thankfully leaves lives and game overs out of the equation. The result is a game with a high challenge but that never feels punishing or impossible and moves forward at lightning speed.

Also welcome is the open world game design that makes VVVVVV feel Metroidvania-esque. Different areas of the map have different sorts of obstacles and challenges, allowing you to explore and progress at your own pace.

Another interesting aspect is the game's story, which does not feature a villain or enemies of any kind. The story feels like a small side quest happening in a larger world, which is a refreshing change from a typical platformer where you need to save the world/princess.

It also has one of the best chiptune tracks that you will ever hear and features simple but effective graphics inspired by C64 games.

Overall, VVVVVV is an immensely satisfying experience for anyone up to the challenge and I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
This game is an absolute masterpiece. Very few games can keep people playing after dying hundreds of times. I'm guessing that it has something to do with the amazing music present in the game. If you're playing for the first time, you'll likely finish the story in 2-3 hours with maybe 600 or so deaths.

Fortunately, completing the story is only part of the fun. If you're going for 100%, you'll also have a chance to experience the joy of going back through the game and hunting down all 20 Trinkets (I'm sure you'll love the Veni Vidi Vici Trinket) the insane speed trials (Where you have to complete levels in the game within a pre-determined time frame), the more-than fun Super Gravitron (Your goal is to survive 1 full minute during which all you can do is move left and right to avoid a never-ending onslaught of obstacles coming from both sides. My personal best for that is a bit above 20 seconds), and of course, trying to get the hardest achievement in the game, which is...

...No Death Mode

As the name implies, you have to beat the entire game with only 1 life. Screw up even once, and you're back at the start. You're guaranteed to have fun dodging broken hearts, surviving the Gravitron for 60 seconds straight, avoiding spikes, and clinging on to dear life in the Dial M For Murder room.

If you find that mode too easy, you can always do an all-trinket no death run, I guess.

reviewText:
This is a very fun platformer, but I can only recommend it on a condition: if bright lights and strobes do not affect you. Some of the levels are intense, and I found myself sort of spacing out and getting lost in the bright colorful lights. I can't imagine what this would do to someone with epilepsy, but it would definitely be very bad. As it is, I had to turn it off after playing the same level for about five minutes and not being able to make the jump because it was changing between screens so rapidly and the colors were so bright that I couldn't take it. And I'm not epileptic, I've never had this kind of problem with a game before. So yes, I recommend it, in short doses to people who aren't bothered by strobes of light and color. But I can't imagine myself playing this for an hour or two straight, it's really more of a take five minutes to enjoy the soundtrack" kind of game.

reviewText:
OK, a serious review this time - maybe this game simply wasn't *for* me. I've never really been a fan of retro-styled platformers, probably because I didn't grow up with them so the nostalgia doesn't really do anything for me. I've tried to play some of the classics but the ones that do hold up (Mega Man, Gimmick!) still have plenty of gameplay flaws that their indie counterparts don't seem to want to let go of.

VVVVVV has a great, great soundtrack (I even bought it) but it's an immensely frustating game in a way that it's arcade contemporary Super Meat Boy is not. You respawn instantly, like that game, but with an irritating sound effect that feels like a punishment for dying. The odd control scheme is slippery and feels inconsistent, although I'll admit some people have mastered it enough to speedrun it. And, unlike many of Super Meat Boy's levels where you see what is coming far before tackling it, VVVVVV by design blindsides you with its Zelda-style screen scrolls into traps you have no time to prepare for. Veni Vidi Vici is the quintessential example of this design philosophy in action.

What this results in is a game that is entirely based on trial-and-error. That's really all it has - the actual platforming isn't fun due to the slow pace and iffy controls, so what it does instead is throw a bunch of gimmicks at you while you slowly inch your way through an Atari-skinned meat grinder. There's some elements of exploration in the hub world (one of the songs is even called Passion For Exploring) but nothing to really do in it, making it just a fancy version of a level select.

This could all be fine if the game was charming or interesting enough to make up for these flaws (Gimmick! is also a frustrating game with a lot of trial-and-error) but, unfortunately, it really isn't. The characters are literally stick figures. The world is mostly blocks and spikes with an occasionally cute theme or object in a room, reinforced by the nice touch of giving every room its own name, but its very barebones.

Obviously, many people have enjoyed VVVVVV a lot, and saying something binary like this game is the worst thing ever" is silly and unfair. But my honest opinion is that it's just not worth the short time you put into it."

reviewText:
AUDIO: Cute                                                                      AESTHETIC: Basic
MEMORABILITY: Reasonable                                      WORTH: Light Discount

PROS: Similar to You Have To Win The Game, VVVVVV is a Montezuma's Revenge-style game that features puzzles, platforming, action, collecting, and exploration. This type of game lends itself very well to the low tech style, and in my opinion is the best genre a game that emulates Atari or C64 has to offer. It has plenty of hours of gameplay and quick respawn for instant retrying. Music is very catchy and endearing. Story is interesting.

CONS: I had run into several game-breaking glitches while playing. Even after I had restarted and reinstalled, the game malfunctioned in similar places. This made the game nearly unfinishable for me. It took three attempts to make it through without getting stuck in limbo, which was very frustrating.

OVERALL: Despite its glitchiness, I had a lot of fun with VVVVVV. There have been recent updates (Including Steam Achievements!) So I have faith that eventually, the game will be largely without flaw.

SCORE: 6/10

reviewText:
VVVVVV is a simple platformer released in 2010 which simplifies it's basics into one rule: what if you reverse gravity instead of jumping? This is an interesting rule used in this game and it impacts on how you play the game, too. No skill is required to play this game; you can simply pick up the game and discover things as you go through.

So, VVVVVV is about Captain Viridian and his crew in space on the D.S.S Souleye, which then the flight to an unknown area has been interrupted, and the crew has to evacuate, however the evacuation goes wrong and Viridian is left on his own requiring him to save his crew members in Dimension VVVVVV. The plot seems interesting, however the only thing concerned is that the characters never mention the year, assuming it is in the future due to the teleport technology used. They do not also mention age, and gender, although colors and personality shape the genders of the characters.

The difficulty of the game is similar to Super Meat Boy: the difficulty is simple on the first stages like the introduction level and onward from the Lab, it gets challenging.

Overall, this game is good except the fact that if you don't like difficulty, please leave.
I'd rate this game a 9/10.

This game also has good music. BUY THE SOUNDTRACK!

reviewText: VVVVVV is a challenging yet short indie platformer that is well worth the cost and a lovely fun time as a whole. The game's main innovative platforming mechanic of doing away with jumps and instead allowing the player to flip gravity in the opposite direction is delightfully fun and memorable. The characters in the game are likable even without a gripping, dramatic story and long dialogues, and the environment is easy to understand and fun to explore. Overall, the game has an atmosphere that's hard to describe perfectly, I feel. This game's only noticable short-coming, if I had to give it one, is its length; it's not too terribly long, giving the average player somewhere in the ballpark of six to twelve hours of gameplay. However short this game is, though, I absolutely recommend it. Great things come in small packages, eh? Terry Cavanagh did an excellent job as a lone developer.\n\nSpecial attention must be paid to this game's music, composed by Magnus Pålsson. This game is worth the price you pay just for the game's soundtrack alone. I'm a video game music aficionado, and this game has one of my favorite soundtracks amongst all games I've ever played. Please, do yourself a favor and either play this game or find and listen to the soundtrack by itself. Add this amazing music to a wonderful, impressionable game? Just, damn... it's too good. It's truly incredible.

reviewText: VVVVVV takes its name from the game's main objective, which I shall not touch upon in order to leave the discovery to you. The first aspect of the game that took me by surprise is the superb 8-bit chiptune music. The only problem with that is that it does get repetitive only because it replays one single track for about 30 minutes at a time, until you complete each level. The graphics are imitating the general style of the Commodore 64, including its startup screen. VVVVVV's main platforming mechanic is the player's ability to flip the character's screen position vertically, going from bottom to top and vice versa. This makes for some complicated platforming in general, as well as some challenging and entertaining rooms. Because of the game's incredible difficulty, the developers have cleverly implemented checkpoints liberally throughout the game world, which cuts down on rage and frustration. With that said, VVVVVV still manages to be extremely difficult, and you should expect to die hundreds of times, if not one thousand times by the time you complete the game. The platforming and controls are not badly designed, as in Super Meat Boy, so do not confuse this well crafted, yet simplistic game with that developmental disaster. Younger generations of gamers may find the overall presentation of VVVVVV to be unique and hip, but as we all know, these graphics have been done before, about 30 years ago. One serious flaw is that there are no audio options for volume. The in-game default is quite higher than usual, and requires turning down in Windows. While the majority of the levels' rooms are a lot of fun, and well designed, some are simply unreasonable and require too much luck as opposed to actual precision and skill. Because of this, you will die many times and spend far too long attempting single rooms. Which also means being forced to listen to a single song on a loop, for the entire duration of your trials. This is something of a shortcoming and should have been avoided completely by the developers, as these uncalled-for rooms only add negatively to the experience. Even though you get unlimited lives and unlimited continues, having to repeat a single room hundreds of times in order to pass it gets boring, repetitive, annoying, and only serves the purpose of replacing actual content with limited and mundane game play. While the music is once again, excellent, there are only a few that repeat over and over, as the rest must be unlocked by finding and collecting certain orbs within the game world. There are also a few more game modes for the player to experiment with once the campaign has been completed. The storyline and ending are endearing and delightful, and once you complete the game, there is an overall feeling of satisfaction. VVVVVV is short but perfectly sweet.\n\nVVVVVV is good.
